## Quick‑look numbers for “one typical plant in one year”

Below is a **back‑of‑the‑envelope** calculation that turns the *deaths‑per‑TWh* rates you saw earlier into **how many people would be expected to die because of one specific plant’s electricity output in a single calendar year**.

| Plant type | Typical name‑plate capacity | Real‑world capacity factor* | Electricity produced in 1 yr (TWh) | Death‑rate used for the illustration | Expected deaths in that year |
|------------|----------------------------|----------------------------|------------------------------------|--------------------------------------|------------------------------|
| **Coal‑fired** | 500 MW (mid‑size “supercritical” unit) | 85 % (modern, well‑maintained) | **3.73 TWh** | 25 deaths / TWh (mid‑range of 20‑30) | **≈ 0.09 deaths** (about **1 death every 11 years**) |
| **Nuclear** | 1 200 MW (large pressurised‑water reactor) | 90 % (typical for OECD plants) | **9.5 TWh** | 0.07 deaths / TWh (mid‑range of 0.04‑0.2) | **≈ 0.0007 deaths** (about **1 death every 1 400 years**) |

\*Capacity factor = *actual output ÷ maximum possible output* over a year.  It reflects downtime for maintenance, fuel handling, etc.  Modern coal plants in the U.S./EU run at 75‑85 % CF; modern nuclear reactors in the same regions run at 90‑95 % CF.

---

### How the numbers are derived  

#### 1.  Electricity produced by the plant  

\[
\text{Energy (TWh)} = \frac{\text{Capacity (MW)} \times 8760\ \text{h/yr} \times \text{CF}}{10^{6}}
\]

*Coal plant*  
\[
500\ \text{MW} \times 8760\ \text{h} \times 0.85 = 3.73 \times 10^{9}\ \text{kWh}=3.73\ \text{TWh}
\]

*Nuclear plant*  
\[
1\,200\ \text{MW} \times 8760\ \text{h} \times 0.90 = 9.5 \times 10^{9}\ \text{kWh}=9.5\ \text{TWh}
\]

#### 2.  Apply the “deaths per TWh” factor  

\[
\text{Deaths} = \text{Energy (TWh)} \times \frac{\text{Deaths}}{\text{TWh}}
\]

*Coal*  
\[
3.73\ \text{TWh} \times 25\ \frac{\text{deaths}}{\text{TWh}} = 93.3\ \text{deaths per 100 years} \approx 0.09\ \text{deaths per year}
\]

*Nuclear*  
\[
9.5\ \text{TWh} \times 0.07\ \frac{\text{deaths}}{\text{TWh}} = 0.665\ \text{deaths per 100 years} \approx 0.0007\ \text{deaths per year}
\]

---

| Source of risk | Coal (≈ 0.09 deaths/yr) | Nuclear (≈ 0.0007 deaths/yr) |

| **Fuel‑handling / plant‑operation accidents** | 0.001–0.005 deaths/yr (rare but not negligible).
